H0.text: two main types of research methods used in psychology. Experimental

H1.text: two main types of research methods used in psychology. Statistical

H2.text: two main types of research methods used in psychology. Clinical

H3.text: two main types of research methods used in psychology. qualitative

A4.text: The use of experimental methods was perhaps the main characteristic by which psychology became distinguishable from philosophy in the late 19th century.

A5.text: Other methods of research such as case studies, interviews, opinion polls and naturalistic observation, are often used by psychologists.

A6.text: Quantitative psychological research lends itself to the statistical testing of hypotheses.

A7.text: Some psychologists rely on less rigorously controlled, but more ecologically valid, field experiments as well.

A8.text: The independent variable is manipulated by the experimenter, and the dependent variable is measured.

A9.text: When used, however, experiments typically follow the form of the clinical trial, where experimental units (usually individual human beings) are randomly assigned to a treatment or control condition where one or more outcomes are assessed.
